children.text:
Now, the Fortran code structure:

program main

    implicit none

    integer :: x, t, a, b, da, db
    integer :: i, j, first, second
    logical :: ok

    read(*,*) x, t, a, b, da, db

    ok = .false. do i = 0, t-1
        first = a - da * i
        do j = 0, t-1
            second = b - db * j
            if ( (first + second == x) .or. (second == x) .or. (first == x) .or. (x == 0) ) then
                ok = .true.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Thus, the Fortran code should look like the outline I wrote.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
exit
            end if
        end do
        if (ok) exit
    end do

    if (ok) then
        print *, "YES"
    else
        print *, "NO"
    end if

end program main

So that's correct.

Okay, I need to translate this Java code into Fortran. Let me start by understanding what the Java code does. 

The code seems to check if a certain value x can be obtained by either one of two values, first and second, which decrease over time. The variables first and second are calculated in nested loops. For each time step i up to t, first is a minus da multiplied by i. Similarly, for each j up to t, second is b minus db multiplied by j. Then, it checks if the sum of first and second equals x, or if either of them individually equals x, or if x is zero. If any of these conditions are met, it sets ok to true.

So, in Fortran, I need to replicate this logic. Let's think about the structure.

First, in Java, the code reads input using BufferedReader and StringTokenizer. Fortran uses READ statements for input. The variables x, t, a, b, da, db are integers. So in Fortran, we can read them using a single READ statement.

Then, the nested loops for i and j from 0 to t-1 (since Java's for loop is for (i=0; i < t; i++)). In Fortran, loops are typically written as do loops. So, the outer loop would be do i = 0, t-1, and similarly for j.

Inside the loops, compute first and second. Then check if their sum is x, or if either is x, or x is zero. If any condition is met, set a logical variable (say, ok) to .true. and exit the loops.

But Fortran doesn't have a direct break statement for nested loops. So when a condition is met, we need to exit both loops. Maybe using flags to exit the inner loop and then check in the outer loop.

Alternatively, once ok is set to true, we can exit all loops. Let's structure it with loops and exit conditions.

Another thing: the Java code initializes ok as false. So in Fortran, we can have a logical variable ok initialized to .false.

Also, after the loops, print "YES" or "NO" based on ok.

1. Read the input values x, t, a, b, da, db.

Wait, in the Java code, the order of reading is x, t, a, b, da, db. So in Fortran, we need to read them in the same order.

Now, the Fortran code structure:

program main

    implicit none

    integer :: x, t, a, b, da, db
    integer :: i, j, first, second
    logical :: ok

    read(*,*) x, t, a, b, da, db

    ok = .false.

    do i = 0, t-1
        first = a - da * i
        do j = 0, t-1
            second = b - db * j
            if ( (first + second == x) .or. (second == x) .or. (first == x) .or. (x == 0) ) then
                ok = .true.
                exit
            end if
        end do
        if (ok) exit
    end do

    if (ok) then
        print *, "YES"
    else
        print *, "NO"
    end if

end program main
